title: Assignment 1
text:
2. Run Fall.R (on class GitHub under R)

# Title Fall color
# Credit: https://fronkonstin.com
  
# Install packages
  
#install.packages("gsubfn")
#install.packages("tidyverse")
library(gsubfn)

Warning: package 'gsubfn' was built under R version 4.1.3


Loading required package: proto


Warning: package 'proto' was built under R version 4.1.3

library(tidyverse)

Warning: package 'tidyverse' was built under R version 4.1.3


-- Attaching packages --------------------------------------- tidyverse 1.3.2 --


v ggplot2 3.3.6     v purrr   0.3.4
v tibble  3.1.8     v dplyr   1.0.9
v tidyr   1.2.0     v stringr 1.4.0
v readr   2.1.2     v forcats 0.5.2


Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.1.3


Warning: package 'tibble' was built under R version 4.1.3


Warning: package 'tidyr' was built under R version 4.1.3


Warning: package 'readr' was built under R version 4.1.3


Warning: package 'purrr' was built under R version 4.1.3


Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 4.1.3


Warning: package 'stringr' was built under R version 4.1.3


Warning: package 'forcats' was built under R version 4.1.3


-- Conflicts ------------------------------------------ tidyverse_conflicts() --
x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
x dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()

# Define elements in plant art
# Each image corresponds to a different axiom, rules, angle and depth

# Leaf of Fall

axiom="X"
rules=list("X"="F-[[X]+X]+F[+FX]-X", "F"="FF")
angle=22.5
depth=6


for (i in 1:depth) axiom=gsubfn(".", rules, axiom)

actions=str_extract_all(axiom, "\\d*\\+|\\d*\\-|F|L|R|\\[|\\]|\\|") %>% unlist

status=data.frame(x=numeric(0), y=numeric(0), alfa=numeric(0))
points=data.frame(x1 = 0, y1 = 0, x2 = NA, y2 = NA, alfa=90, depth=1)


# Generating data
# Note: may take a minute or two

for (action in actions)
{
  if (action=="F")
  {
    x=points[1, "x1"]+cos(points[1, "alfa"]*(pi/180))
    y=points[1, "y1"]+sin(points[1, "alfa"]*(pi/180))
    points[1,"x2"]=x
    points[1,"y2"]=y
    data.frame(x1 = x, y1 = y, x2 = NA, y2 = NA,
               alfa=points[1, "alfa"],
               depth=points[1,"depth"]) %>% rbind(points)->points
  }
  if (action %in% c("+", "-")){
    alfa=points[1, "alfa"]
    points[1, "alfa"]=eval(parse(text=paste0("alfa",action, angle)))
  }
  if(action=="["){
    data.frame(x=points[1, "x1"], y=points[1, "y1"], alfa=points[1, "alfa"]) %>%
      rbind(status) -> status
    points[1, "depth"]=points[1, "depth"]+1
  }
  
  if(action=="]"){
    depth=points[1, "depth"]
    points[-1,]->points
    data.frame(x1=status[1, "x"], y1=status[1, "y"], x2=NA, y2=NA,
               alfa=status[1, "alfa"],
               depth=depth-1) %>%
      rbind(points) -> points
    status[-1,]->status
  }
}

ggplot() +
  geom_segment(aes(x = x1, y = y1, xend = x2, yend = y2),
               lineend = "round",
               color="firebrick", # Set your own Fall color?
               data=na.omit(points)) +
  coord_fixed(ratio = 1) +
  theme_void() # No grid nor axes






3. Write a critique on a chart in published work (book/article/news website)



Data Visualization Retrieved from Flowingdata.com, posted on August 31, 2022


This visualization lacks elements on multiple fronts:

A title is missing from the figure. Thereby, causing confusion as to what information is being relayed via the visualization.
There is no scaling information provided.
The lack of a legend or key, makes the colorization and color-coding confusing; leading to questions such as what do the colors dictate? Do the differences in colors have significance? I would assume that the colors is a way to divide the the United States; however, what is the division based on?
The figure does not yield a high informative power; that is, I am not really inferring much from the visualization.

In conclusion, while this visualization is certainly colorful and beautiful to look at, it does not convey information well; and therefore, does not serve the basic purpose of data visualization.

title: Assignment 2
text:
Plotting Functions Using the Happy Planet Data set

#importing data into R 
library(readxl)

Warning: package 'readxl' was built under R version 4.1.3

my_data <- read.csv("C:/Users/elmor/Downloads/HPI.csv")

#column 
colnames(my_data)<-c("hpi_rank","country","iso","year",
                    "continent", "population", "life_expectancy",
                    "ladder_of_life", "ecological_footprint",
                    "hpi", "biocapacity_for_year", "gdp")

#na removal


mydata <- na.omit(my_data)

#plotting functions

year <- c(2013, 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019)
hpi_score <- aggregate(hpi ~ year, mydata, mean)
life_score  <- aggregate(life_expectancy ~ year, mydata, mean)
hpi_score <- c(hpi_score$hpi)
life_score <- c(life_score$life_expectancy)

# Setting the parameter
par(mfrow=c(3, 2))

#labeling, margins c(bottom, left, top, right) & size
par(las=1, mar=c(4, 4, 2, 4), cex=.7) 
plot.new()
plot.window(range(year), c(40, 80))
lines(year, hpi_score)
lines(year, life_score)
points(year, hpi_score, pch=17, bg = "blue", cex=4)  
points(year, life_score, pch=21, bg ="red", cex=4) 
par(col="gray50", fg="gray50", col.axis="gray50")
axis(1, at=seq(2013, 2019, 2)) 
axis(2, at=seq(40, 80, 10))
axis(4, at=seq(40, 80, 10))
box(bty="u")
mtext("year", side=1, line=2, cex=0.8)
mtext("HPI", side=2, line=2, las=0, cex=0.8)
mtext("Life Exp", side=4, line=2, las=0, cex=0.8)
text(4, 5, "Bird 131")
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1), col="black", fg="black", col.axis="black")


#Histogram

par(mar=c(4.5, 4.1, 3.1, 0))
hist(mydata$hpi, breaks=seq(floor(min(mydata$hpi)),
                             ceiling(max(mydata$hpi))), 
     main="Height histogram", xlab="HPI", 
     col="gray", freq=FALSE)
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1))



#Barplot
library(dplyr)

Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 4.1.3



Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

my_data3 <- my_data %>%
  mutate(gdp_lev = ifelse(my_data$gdp >= 31202, 'high',
                          ifelse(my_data$gdp >= 4985, 'middle',
                                 'low')))

summary(my_data$hpi)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.    NA's 
  22.35   38.32   44.20   44.02   49.73   64.73      58 

my_data3 <- my_data3 %>%
  mutate(hpi_lev = ifelse(my_data$hpi > 49, 'good',
                          ifelse(my_data$hpi > 39, 'average',
                                 'bad')))

gdp_sub_h <- subset(my_data3, gdp_lev == "high")
aggregate(gdp_lev ~ hpi_lev, gdp_sub_h, length)

  hpi_lev gdp_lev
1 average     122
2     bad      50
3    good      75

gdp_sub_m <- subset(my_data3, gdp_lev == "middle")
aggregate(gdp_lev ~ hpi_lev, gdp_sub_m, length)

  hpi_lev gdp_lev
1 average     223
2     bad      96
3    good     175

hpi_le <- c("average", "bad", "good")
high <- c(122, 50, 75)
middle <- c(223, 96, 175)
low <- c(85, 134, 28)

bar_df <- data.frame(high, middle, low)
rownames(bar_df)=hpi_le

par(mar=c(2, 3.1, 2, 2.1))
midpts <- barplot(as.matrix(bar_df), names = rep("", 3),
                  col = c("white", "pink", "blue"))
legend("topright", inset=.02,
       c("average","bad", "good"), fill = c("white", "pink", "blue"), 
       horiz=FALSE, cex=0.5)
mtext("GDP per capita", side=3, line=0.0, cex=0.5)
mtext(sub(" ", "\n", colnames(bar_df)),
      at=midpts, side=1, line=0.5, cex=0.5)

par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1))  

#Boxplot

par(mar=c(2, 4, 1, 0.5))
boxplot(my_data3$hpi ~ my_data3$gdp_lev, data = my_data3,
        boxwex = 0.4, at = 1:3 - 0.2,
        subset= my_data3$hpi_lev == "good", col="pink",
        xlab="",
        ylab="HPI", ylim=c(20,70))
mtext("GDP per capita", side=1, line=1.8, cex=0.5)

boxplot(my_data3$hpi ~ my_data3$gdp_lev, data = my_data3, add = TRUE,
        boxwex = 0.4, at = 1:3 + 0.2,
        subset= my_data3$hpi_lev == "bad", col="red")
legend("bottomleft", inset=.02,
       c("good","bad"), fill = c("pink", "red"), horiz=TRUE, cex=0.5)
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1))

# Piechart
par(mar=c(0, 2, 1, 2), xpd=FALSE, cex=0.5)
pie.sales <- c(0.11, 0.06, 0.23, 0.11, 0.12, 0.37)
names(pie.sales) <- c("Africa", "Asia",
                      "Europe", "Oceania", "Others", "South America")
pie(pie.sales, col = rainbow(7))

title: About Me
text:
I am a PhD student at the University of Texas at Dallas’ School of Economic, Political, and Policy Sciences (EPPS).My research interests lie in the comparative politics; protests and social movements of the Southwest Asian and North African (SWANA) region.
Specifically, I seek to concretely explore the impacts of protest and social movement’s activity. Particularly, in terms of protest participation methods, campaign objectives and their achievement, and the involvement of state-repression in protest campaign success.
Born and raised in Cairo, Egypt; I have long been passionate about understanding the political and social dynamics of political behavior and participation in the SWANA region.
When I am not buried under code and seminal works, I enjoy drinking caramel-flavored coffee, taking naps, and hiking.

title: Assignment 3
text:
Using Other Packages

library(ggplot2)

ggplot(lm1, aes(x = x1, y = y1)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(x = "X1", y = "Y1 score")





# conditional plots
par(mfrow=c(4,4)) #for multiple plot display

library(ggplot2)
#install.packages("visreg")
library(visreg)

Warning: package 'visreg' was built under R version 4.1.3

visreg(lm1, "x1", gg = TRUE) 



visreg(lm2, "x2", gg = TRUE)



visreg(lm3, "x3", gg = TRUE)



visreg(lm4, "x4", gg = TRUE)





#Visualizing Regression model via Table
#install.packages("stargazer")
library(stargazer)


Please cite as:

Specifically, I seek to concretely explore the impacts of protest and social movement’s activity. Particularly, in terms of protest participation methods, campaign objectives and their achievement, and the involvement of state-repression in protest campaign success.
Born and raised in Cairo, Egypt; I have long been passionate about understanding the political and social dynamics of political behavior and participation in the SWANA region.
When I am not buried under code and seminal works, I enjoy drinking caramel-flavored coffee, taking naps, and hiking.
